Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Expectation2: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation2: They wear gloves occasionally when handling certain cleaning tasks.
Story: I was halfway through scrubbing the kitchen floor at the hotel, my hands sweating inside the thick rubber gloves, when my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a message from my younger brother: “Can you talk? I really need you.” My heart squeezed. He never asked for help unless it was serious. I glanced at the clock—my supervisor would be making rounds soon, and I still had two rooms left to clean. The rules were clear: no phones during work, gloves on at all times, and no distractions. But my brother’s words echoed in my mind. As a sister, I was supposed to be there for him, especially when he was struggling. But as a cleaner, I was expected to put the job and its protocols first. I stared at my gloved hands, torn between peeling them off to call him and risking a reprimand, or ignoring his plea and finishing my shift as expected. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, and I stood frozen, caught between duty and family.
